file_name: .Listening is a six-part process that can be remembered through its acronym, the HURIER listening profile (Brownell, 1996) What are the six-parts of this profile?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Listening is a six-part process that can be remembered through its acronym, the HURIER listening profile (Brownell, 1996) What are the six-parts of this profile?.md
subject: communication
question_text: Listening is a six-part process that can be remembered through its acronym, the HURIER listening profile (Brownell, 1996) What are the six-parts of this profile?
answer_text:
Hearing: perceiving sounds and movements communicated by others verbally and nonverbally this also includes signs and gestures, such as when someone is communicating with American Sign Language.

Understanding: making sense of the verbal and Nonverbal cues that are being perceived, which requires undersstanding the words and language being spoken or signed

Remembering: storing the words in your memory long enough to further process what was said or signed

Interpreting: making meaning out of the combination of all the verbal and nonverbal messages that were conveyed during the interaction

Evaluating: making judgments about the message and deciding whether it is true or false, positive or negative, etc.

Responding: signaling that you have received the message and giving verbal and/or nonverbal feedback

file_name: .Solve sec(θ) = 2cos(θ) to find the first four positive solutions.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Solve sec(θ) = 2cos(θ) to find the first four positive solutions.md
subject: mathematics
question_text: Solve sec(θ) = 2cos(θ) to find the first four positive solutions
answer_text:
θ = π/4 , 3π/4, 5π/4, 7π/4
sec(θ) = 2cos(θ)
1 / cos(θ) = 2cos(θ)
1 = 2cos²(θ)
1/2 = cos²(θ)
√1/2 = cos(θ) # remember the square gives a + or - solution
cos(θ) = ±√1⁄2 = ± √2/2
cos⁻¹(±√1⁄2) = π/3 , 3π/4, 5π/4, 7π/4

file_name: .Solve tan(x) = 3sin(x) for all solutions with 0 ≤ x < 2π.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Solve tan(x) = 3sin(x) for all solutions with 0 ≤ x < 2π.md
subject: mathematics
question_text: Solve tan(x) = 3sin(x) for all solutions with 0 ≤ x < 2π (calculator to get final value)
answer_text:
x = 0, 1.231, π, 5.052 
Solution
tan(x) = 3sin(x) #Rewrite tan(x)
sin(x)/cos(x) = 3sin(x) # Now multiply to eliminate the fraction
sin(x) = 3sin(x)*cos(x) # don't divide by sin(x)
sin(x) - 3sin(x)*cos(x) # Factor out sin(x)
sin(x)(1-3cos(x)) = 0
sin⁻¹(0), π - sin⁻¹ = x # solutions for sin(x)
(1-3cos(x)) = 0 -> cos(x) = -1 / -3
cos⁻¹(1/3), -cos⁻¹(1/3) + 2π = x # solutions for cos(x)

file_name: .Why would you use the sandbox attribute with an iframe?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Why would you use the sandbox attribute with an iframe?.md
subject: web_design
question_text: Why would you use the sandbox attribute with an iframe? Name the four values you can enter into this attribute.
answer_text:
The sandbox attribute is used with an <iframe> element to restrict what the embedded content can do. 

allow-scripts: allows the embedded content to run scripts
allow-same-origin: Allows the embedded content to be treated as being from the same origin as the containing document
allow-forms: Allows the embedded content to submit forms
allow-popups: Allows the embedded content to open new windows or tabs.

By default the iframe is unrestricted

file_name: .According to Roman legend, which of the following creatures suckled Romulus and Remes after they were abandoned?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/According to Roman legend, which of the following creatures suckled Romulus and Remes after they were abandoned?.md
subject: mythology
question_text: According to Roman legend, which of the following creatures suckled Romulus and Remes after they were abandoned?
answer_text:
A Wolf

"The origins of Rome, as of all ancient cities, are wrapped in fable. The Roman fable is of Romulus and Remus, twin sons of Mars, abandoned on the flooding Tiber and deposited by the receding waters at the foot of the Palatine. Suckled by a she-wolf, they were reared by a shepherd and grew up to found Rome. (The bronze statue of the maternally ferocious wolf, now in the city’s Capitoline Museums, is one of the best-known works among the thousands of masterpieces in Rome.)"

file_name: .According to Greek Mythology, who captured Pegasus and rode him in his fight with the Chimera?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/According to Greek Mythology, who captured Pegasus and rode him in his fight with the Chimera?.md
subject: mythology
question_text: According to Greek Mythology, who captured Pegasus and rode him in his fight with the Chimera?
answer_text:
Bellerophon 

"The winged horse Pegasus sprang from the blood of the Gorgon Medusa as she was beheaded by the hero Perseus. With Athena’s (or Poseidon’s) help, another Greek hero, Bellerophon, captured Pegasus and rode him first in his fight with the Chimera and later while he was taking vengeance on Stheneboea (Anteia), who had falsely accused Bellerophon. Subsequently Bellerophon attempted to fly with Pegasus to heaven but was unseated and killed or, by some accounts, lamed. The winged horse became a constellation and the servant of Zeus."

file_name: .An object is connected to the wall with a spring that has a natural length of 20cm. Find an equation, how much time during each cycle is the object more than 27cm from the wall?.md

question_text: An object is connected to the wall with a spring that has a natural length of 20 cm. The object is pulled back 8 cm past the natural length and released.  Starting from the furthest position from the wall. The object oscillates 3 times per second. Find an equation for the horizontal position of the object ignoring the effects of friction. How much time during each cycle is the object more than 27 cm from the wall?
answer_text:
To find the equation:
amplitude is range / 2 = (28 - 12) /2 = 8
midline is 20 as described
8cos(6πθ) + 20
solve for 27 = 8 * sin(6πθ) + 20

Solution:
θ = 0.505 / 6π

file_name: .In Greek and Roman mythology, who are the twin deities who aid shipwrecked sailors?.md

subject: mythology
question_text: In Greek and Roman mythology, who are the twin deities who aid shipwrecked sailors?
answer_text:
The Dioscuri (Castor and Pollux)

"The Dioscuri (Castor and Pollux) are twin deities who succour shipwrecked sailors and receive sacrifices for favourable winds. They are the children of Leda and either Zeus, the king of the gods, or Tyndareus, Leda’s mortal husband and the king of Lacedaemon. According to the usual version, Castor is the son of Tyndareus and thus is mortal, while Pollux is the son of Zeus (who famously had approached Leda in the form of a swan)."

file_name: .Solve 3sec²(t) - 5sec(t) = 0 for all solutions with 0 ≤ t < 2π.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Solve 3sec²(t) - 5sec(t) = 0 for all solutions with 0 ≤ t < 2π.md
subject: mathematics
question_text: Solve 3sec²(t) - 5sec(t) = 0 for all solutions with 0 ≤ t < 2π
answer_text:
3sec²(t) - 5sec(t) = 0
Factor
(3sec(t)+1)(sec(t)-2)
3sec(t) + 1 = 0 and sec(t) -2 = 0
sec(t) = -1/3 and sec(t) = 2/1
1/cos(t) = -1/3 and 1/cos(t) = 2/1
cos(t) = -3 and cos(t) = 1/2
inverse function to get the solutions
arccos(-3) = t is invalid: so no solutions
arccos(1/2) = t yield result π/3 and 5π/3

file_name: .The hours of daylight in Seattle oscillate from a low of 8.5 hours in January to a high of . . When should you plant a garden if you want to o it during a month where there are 14 hours of daylight?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/The hours of daylight in Seattle oscillate from a low of 8.5 hours in January to a high of . . When should you plant a garden if you want to o it during a month where there are 14 hours of daylight?.md
subject: mathematics
question_text: The hours of daylight in Seattle oscillate from a low of 8.5 hours in January to a high of 16 hours in July (www.mountaineers.org/seattle/...ylightHrs.html). When should you plant a garden if you want to do it during a month where there are 14 hours of daylight?
answer_text:
First we need an equation to solve, since we have the high and low points, and an indicator January of when the graph starts. We can get an equation.
We start in January with a low point of 8.5
so: ?-cos(?θ)+? : theta being time
midline is 8.5 + amplitude = 12.25
amplitude is the range / 2 = 3.75
period is 12 months or 12 = 2π/b -> B =π/6
solving for 14 hours
14 = -3.75cos(π/6 * θ)+12.25
(14 - 12.25) / -3.75 = cos(π/6 * θ)
cos⁻¹(-1.75 / 3.75) = π/6 * θ
both solutions are 
-cos⁻¹(-1.75/3.75) + 2π, cos⁻¹(-1.75 / 3.75) = π/6 * θ
divide by π/6 on both sides to get both values of t
t₁ to get the month (3.927 months past january)

file_name: .A cable that anchors the center of the London Eye Ferris wheel to the ground must be replaced. what angle and how long is the cable?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/A cable that anchors the center of the London Eye Ferris wheel to the ground must be replaced. what angle and how long is the cable?.md
subject: mathematics
question_text: A cable that anchors the center of the London Eye Ferris wheel to the ground must be replaced. The center of the Ferris wheel is 70 meters above the ground and the second anchor on the ground is 23 meters from the base of the wheel. What is the angle from the ground up to the center of the Ferris wheel? and how long is the cable?
answer_text:
tan(θ) = 70/23 
so the angle is θ = tan⁻¹(70/23)
the length of the cable can be found with the pythagoreum theorum
length = √(70²+23²)

71.83° and 73.68m long

subject: communication
question_text: What are four steps to take when speaking on an idea that is difficult to believe?
answer_text:
1. Acknowledge - your audiences everyday undestanding, or "lay" theory, of how the phenomenon works. Consider asking your audience to describe the concept in their own words to better understand their perspective
2. Acknowledge - Why that explanation seems plausible on the surface
3. Explain - why that impression is incorrect or incomplete, show examples that demonstrate why it is not adequate.
4. Explain - the concept or theory more completely and illustrate why it is effective.

subject: mathematics
question_text: What is the process to solve a sinusoidal function?
answer_text:
1. Isolate the trig function on one side of the equation
2. Make a substitution for the inside of the sin, cosine, or tangent (trig function)
3. Use inverse trig functions to find one solution
4. Use symmetries to find a second solution on one cycle (when a second exists)
5. Find additional solutions if needed by adding full periods
6. Undo the substitution

question_text: In Greek and Roman legend, who is gifted the power to transform all that he touches into gold?
answer_text:
King Midas of Phyrgia,

"Midas, in Greek and Roman legend, is a king of Phrygia, known for his foolishness and greed. According to the myth, Midas found the wandering Silenus, the satyr and companion of the god Dionysus. For his kind treatment of Silenus Midas was rewarded by Dionysus with a wish. The king wished that all he touched might turn to gold, but when his food became gold and he nearly starved to death as a result, he realized his error. Dionysus then granted him release by having him bathe in the Pactolus River (near Sardis in modern Turkey), an action to which the presence of alluvial gold in that stream is attributed."

file_name: .Solve 2sin²(t) = 3cos(t).md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Solve 2sin²(t) = 3cos(t).md
subject: mathematics
question_text: Solve 2sin²(t) = 3cos(t)
answer_text:
cos(t) + 2 = 0 has no solutions:
2cos(t) -1 = 0 at t = π/3 , 5π/3

Solution:
2sin²(t) = 3cos(t)
2(1-cos²(t) = 3cos(t)
2 - 2cos²(t) - 3cos(t) = 0
-2cos²(t) - 3cos(t) + 2 = 0
2cos²(t) + 3cos(t) - 2 = 0
2cos²(t) + 4cos(t) - cos(t) - 2 = 0
2cos(t)(cos(t)+2) - 1(cos(t) + 2) = 0
(cos(t)+2)(2cos(t) -1) = 0
cos⁻¹(-2) = t AND cos⁻¹(1/2) = t
arccos(1/2) = π/3 and 5π/3

file_name: .In a video game design.  . . Find the new coordinates of the character.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/In a video game design.  . . Find the new coordinates of the character.md
subject: mathematics
question_text: In a video game design, a map shows the location of other characters relative to the player, who is situated at the origin, and the direction they are facing. A character currently shows on the map at coordinates (-3, 5). If the player rotates counterclockwise by 20 degrees, then the objects in the map will correspondingly rotate 20 degrees clockwise. Find the new coordinates of the character
answer_text:
we can use the equation x = r * cos(θ) and the pythagoreum theorum to get the current radius of the circle. Then add 20° to θ then reenter theta and solve for x.

-3 = √(9+25) * cos(θ)
-3 / √(34) = cos(θ)
θ = cos⁻¹(-3 / √34)

A counter-clockwise rotation would decrease the relative angle so 
x = √34 * cos(θ-20)
y = √(34-x²)
or
y= √34 * sin(θ-20)

file_name: .Steps to factor a polynomial are? Given x²-2x-3 and 2x²-12x+11?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Steps to factor a polynomial are? Given x²-2x-3 and 2x²-12x+11?.md
subject: mathematics
question_text: Steps to factor a polynomial are? Given x²-2x-3 and 2x²-12x+11?
answer_text:
1. If leading coefficient (a) ≠ 1 factor out 1st 2 terms
2. Take 1⁄2 middle term, square term add it into parentheses and then balance.
3. Write ( ) as something squared use 1⁄2 middle term add to x²
Examples:
y = x²-2x-3
y = 1(x²-2x) -3
y = 1(x²-2x+1)-3 -1
y = 1(x²-2x+1)-4
y = 1(x-1)²-4
Example2:
y = 2x²-12x+11
y = 2(x²-6x+3²)+11-(3²*2)
y = 2(x²-6x+9) +11 - 18
y = 2(x²-3)²-7

file_name: .Solve 2sin²(t)-cos(t) = 1 for all solutions with 0 ≤ t < 2π.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Solve 2sin²(t)-cos(t) = 1 for all solutions with 0 ≤ t < 2π.md
subject: mathematics
question_text: Solve 2sin²(t)-cos(t) = 1 for all solutions with 0 ≤ t < 2π
answer_text:
Solution: t = π/3 or t = 5π/3 or t = π
2sin²(t) - cos(t) = 1
Using sin²(t) = 1-cos²(t)
2(1-cos²(t)) - cos(t)=1
Distributing the 2:
2-2cos²(t) - cos(t) = 1
Now we have a quadratic
-2cos²(t)-cos(t) + 1 = 0
Factor (multiply by -1 to simplify factoring
2cos²(t) + cos(t) - 1 = 0
(2cos(t)-1)(cos(t)+1) = 0
2cos(t)-1 = 0 OR cos(t)+1 = 0
cos(t) = 1/2 or cos(t) = -1
t = π/3 or t = 5π/3 or t = π

file_name: .The Battle Buddy System includes core responsibilities you have regarding your battle buddy. What are these responsibilities?.md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/The Battle Buddy System includes core responsibilities you have regarding your battle buddy. What are these responsibilities?.md
subject: us_military
question_text: The Battle Buddy System includes core responsibilities you have regarding your battle buddy. What are these responsibilities?
answer_text:
1. Never Leave your buddy alone
2. Never let your buddy go into an office or room by themselves; even if a drill sergeant, or instructor says it's okay (If it happens, report it)
3. Keep your buddy safe and free from harm
4. Know the whereabouts of your buddy at all times
5. Pass information to your buddy
6. Encourage and support your buddy to train harder and do better
7. Help your buddy solve problems
8. Inform Cadre of any changes in your buddy's behavior

file_name: .Recite the US Army's "The Soldier's Creed".md
file_path: /home/karibar/Documents/Education/Un-Sorted/Recite the US Army's "The Soldier's Creed".md
subject: us_military
question_text: Recite the US Army's "The Soldier's Creed"
answer_text:
I am an American Soldier
I am a warrior and a member of a team
I serve the people of the United States and live the Army Values
I will always place the mission first
I will never accept defeat
I will never quit
I will never leave a fallen comrade
I am disciplined, physically and mentally tough, trained and proficient in my Warrior tasks and drills
I always maintain my arms, my equipment and myself.
